sentence.Network_en: It felt weird going back to Liverpool.

derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English wyrd 'destiny', of Germanic origin. The adjective (late Middle English) originally meant having the power to control destiny, and was used especially in the Weird Sisters, originally referring to the Fates, later the witches in Shakespeare's Macbeth; the latter use gave rise to the sense 'unearthly' (early 19th cent.)

entry.tran: 奇怪的;不寻常的;奇异的
entry.def: If you describe something or someone as weird, you mean that they are strange.

means.word_mean: 1. suggesting the operation of supernatural influences;

sentences.sentence: "stumps...had uncanny shapes as of monstrous creatures"- John Galsworthy
"he could hear the unearthly scream of some curlew piercing the din"- Henry Kingsley
"some trick of the moonlight; some weird effect of shadow"- Bram Stoker

means.word_mean: 怪诞的; 神秘而可怕的; 超然的
